intro: Passerina anthylloides var. vulgaris, commonly known as the common bluebell, is a flowering plant belonging to the Boraginaceae family. It is characterized by its striking blue to violet flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant typically grows in moist, woodland habitats and has lance-shaped leaves with a hairy texture. It is native to parts of Europe and is often found in shaded, well-drained soils. The flowers attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies, contributing to its ecological significance.
